steps.conclusion: The instructions explicitly require using only "2-4 different dimension names across all effects" to ensure consistent trade-off tracking throughout the activity. The response uses 10 unique dimensions: "Response Time", "Memory Usage", "Data Freshness", "System Complexity", "User Experience", "Processing Cost", "Accuracy", "Infrastructure Cost", "System Reliability", and "Feature Completeness". While the dimensions are relevant to each specific step, this violates the constraint intended to create a cohesive game mechanic with a limited set of variables.

The dimensions should be consolidated to meet the 2-4 count constraint. For example, "Infrastructure Cost" and "Processing Cost" could be merged into "Cost"; "Data Freshness", "Accuracy", and "System Reliability" could be merged into "Quality" or "Accuracy"; "User Experience" and "Feature Completeness" could be merged into "User Experience".

testCase.expectations:
TOPIC-SPECIFIC GUIDANCE:

1. ACCURACY CHECK: Algorithm complexity trade-offs must reflect genuine CS principles. Penalize if:
   - Time vs. space trade-offs are misrepresented in consequences
   - Big-O implications are incorrect
   - Consequences don't reflect real algorithmic trade-offs

2. DIMENSION CHECK: Dimensions should represent meaningful algorithmic concerns like:
   - Performance, Memory Efficiency, Code Readability, Maintainability
   - Should NOT include unrelated dimensions like "team morale" for this topic

3. SCENARIO CHECK: The challenge should involve realistic algorithm selection decisions.

4. CONSEQUENCE CHECK: Consequences should explain the real-world impact of algorithmic choices.


EVALUATION CRITERIA:

1. DIMENSION QUALITY: Dimension names used across all effects should:
   - Connect meaningfully to lesson concepts (2-4 unique dimensions total)
   - Create natural tension (trade-off axes)
   - Be consistently named across all effects (same concept = same name)

2. CONSEQUENCE QUALITY: Each option's consequence must:
   - Explain what happens as a result of the choice
   - Connect to lesson concepts (not generic outcomes)
   - Teach something about trade-offs
   - Be consistent with the stated effects (if effect is positive for dimension X, consequence should reflect improvement in X)

3. TRADE-OFF DESIGN: No option should be obviously best. Options should affect multiple dimensions with mixed impacts (e.g., positive for one, negative for another). If one option has all positive effects, penalize.

4. EFFECTS CONSISTENCY: Each option should have 1-3 effects. Dimension names should be reused consistently across options to create meaningful trade-offs (not random unique names for each effect).

5. FORMAT COMPLIANCE: Verify these constraints:
   - intro: Maximum 500 characters
   - steps: 4-6 steps, each with context (max 500 chars), question (max 100 chars), and 3-4 options
   - options: Each with text (max 80 chars), consequence (max 300 chars), effects array (1-3 items with dimension and impact)
   - reflection: Maximum 500 characters

6. PERSONALIZATION: The {{NAME}} placeholder must be used appropriately in intro and dialogue.

7. CONCEPTUAL ACCURACY: Consequences and effects must make sense given the lesson content. If the lesson teaches that X leads to Y, effects should reflect this.

8. DIALOGUE QUALITY: Context must be pure conversation with NO narrator text, NO character name prefixes, NO action descriptions.

9. REFLECTION QUALITY: The reflection must tie the experience back to lesson principles and acknowledge that different approaches have merit.

ANTI-CHECKLIST GUIDANCE (CRITICAL):
- Do NOT penalize for specific scenario choices or dimension names
- Do NOT require specific dimensions by name
- ONLY penalize for: format violations, consequences that don't connect to lesson concepts, obviously dominant options, inconsistent dimension naming, narrator text in dialogue
- Different valid challenge designs exist - assess the quality of what IS provided

explanationSteps.text: Time complexity measures how execution time grows with input size. O(n) means linear growth — double the input, double the time. O(n²) means quadratic — double the input, quadruple the time.
explanationSteps.title: Time Complexity

explanationSteps.text: Space complexity measures memory usage growth. Some algorithms trade time for space — storing precomputed results to avoid recalculation. Others trade space for time — using less memory but computing more.
explanationSteps.title: Space Complexity

explanationSteps.text: The time-space trade-off is fundamental. Hash tables give O(1) lookup but use extra memory. Binary search uses O(1) space but requires sorted data. Choose based on constraints.
explanationSteps.title: Time-Space Trade-off

explanationSteps.text: Amortized analysis looks at average performance over many operations. ArrayList append is usually O(1), but occasionally O(n) when resizing. Amortized, it's still O(1).
explanationSteps.title: Amortized Analysis

explanationSteps.text: Best, average, and worst case can differ dramatically. Quicksort averages O(n log n) but worst-cases to O(n²). Know your data distribution to choose wisely.
explanationSteps.title: Case Analysis

userInput.lessonDescription: Understanding and applying algorithm complexity analysis to make informed trade-offs in software design

steps.conclusion: The model failed the negative constraint regarding dimensions. The instructions explicitly state: 'Use 2-4 different dimensions across all options... Important: dimensions must be consistent across all steps.' The model used at least 11 different dimensions across the steps (Revenue, Market Share, Profit Margin, Brand Position, Customer Satisfaction, Financial Stability, Strategic Position, Market Complexity, Long-term Flexibility, Strategic Flexibility, Operational Complexity). This breaks the intended mechanics of the challenge where specific metrics are tracked throughout.

The model should have restricted itself to a core set of 3 dimensions (e.g., Revenue, Market Share, Profit Margin) to strictly follow the constraints and create a consistent scoring system for the user.

explanationSteps.text: Demand curves slope downward — as price rises, quantity demanded falls. This reflects the law of demand: people buy less when things cost more, all else equal.
explanationSteps.title: The Demand Curve

explanationSteps.text: Supply curves slope upward — as price rises, quantity supplied increases. Higher prices incentivize producers to make more. Lower prices make production less worthwhile.
explanationSteps.title: The Supply Curve

explanationSteps.text: Equilibrium occurs where supply meets demand. At this price, quantity supplied equals quantity demanded. Prices above equilibrium create surplus; prices below create shortage.
explanationSteps.title: Market Equilibrium

explanationSteps.text: Price elasticity measures responsiveness to price changes. Elastic demand (>1) means sales drop sharply with price increases. Inelastic demand (<1) means sales barely change.
explanationSteps.title: Price Elasticity

explanationSteps.text: Shifts vs. movements: A change in price moves along the curve. Changes in other factors (income, preferences, costs) shift the entire curve. This distinction is crucial.
explanationSteps.title: Shifts vs. Movements

userInput.lessonDescription: Applying supply and demand principles to make strategic pricing and market decisions

steps.conclusion: The user instructions explicitly state to 'Use 2-4 different dimensions total'. The response uses 5 unique dimensions: 'Ecosystem Health', 'Community Relations', 'Biodiversity', 'Budget', and 'Habitat Connectivity' (used only once in Step 1). Additionally, Step 4, Option 3 ('Transparent approach') appears to be a universally best option with Positive/Neutral/Positive effects and no negative impact, violating the 'No option should be universally best' requirement.

To fix the dimension count, 'Habitat Connectivity' in Step 1 could be merged into 'Ecosystem Health'. To fix the dominant option in Step 4, the 'Budget' impact should likely be 'negative' to reflect the 'time-consuming' nature of community meetings mentioned in the consequence text, creating a proper trade-off.

explanationSteps.text: Ecosystems are interconnected networks. Removing one species affects others through food webs. Keystone species have disproportionate impact — their loss cascades through the system.
explanationSteps.title: Interconnected Networks

explanationSteps.text: Carrying capacity is the maximum population an environment can sustain. Exceed it, and resources deplete, populations crash. Stay well below, and you're not maximizing the ecosystem's potential.
explanationSteps.title: Carrying Capacity

explanationSteps.text: Biodiversity provides resilience. More species means more ways to respond to change. Monocultures are efficient but fragile. Diverse systems are robust but complex to manage.
explanationSteps.title: Biodiversity and Resilience

explanationSteps.text: Trophic cascades occur when changes at one level ripple through others. Remove predators, and prey populations explode, overgrazing vegetation, affecting everything that depends on those plants.
explanationSteps.title: Trophic Cascades

explanationSteps.text: Ecological succession is the process of change over time. Pioneer species prepare the way for later ones. Managing ecosystems means deciding where in succession you want to be.
explanationSteps.title: Ecological Succession

userInput.lessonDescription: Applying ecological principles to make informed ecosystem management decisions

steps.conclusion: The response is excellent. The choice of dimensions covers the key aspects of chemical process engineering (Yield, Rate, Cost, Equipment Health). The application of Le Chatelier's principle is chemically accurate for the Haber-Bosch process (Pressure, Temperature, Concentration, Removal of Product). The distinction between Thermodynamics (Yield) and Kinetics (Rate) in Step 2 and Step 5 is particularly well handled, which is often a stumbling block in AI content generation for this topic. No significant improvements are needed.

explanationSteps.text: O principio de Le Chatelier diz que um sistema em equilibrio responde a perturbacoes minimizando a mudanca. Adicione reagente, o equilibrio desloca para consumir esse reagente.
explanationSteps.title: Principio de Le Chatelier

explanationSteps.text: Mudancas de concentracao deslocam o equilibrio. Adicionar reagentes desloca para produtos. Remover produtos tambem desloca para produtos. O sistema busca restaurar o equilibrio.
explanationSteps.title: Efeito da Concentracao

explanationSteps.text: A pressao afeta equilibrios gasosos. Aumentar pressao favorece o lado com menos moles de gas. Diminuir pressao favorece o lado com mais moles. Gases inertes nao afetam.
explanationSteps.title: Efeito da Pressao

explanationSteps.text: Temperatura e diferente — ela muda a constante de equilibrio. Reacoes exotermicas: aumento de temperatura desloca para reagentes. Reacoes endotermicas: aumento favorece produtos.
explanationSteps.title: Efeito da Temperatura

explanationSteps.text: Catalisadores aceleram ambas as direcoes igualmente. Eles nao deslocam o equilibrio — apenas ajudam a alcancar o equilibrio mais rapido. Util para processos industriais.
explanationSteps.title: Papel dos Catalisadores

userInput.lessonDescription: Aplicando o principio de Le Chatelier para otimizar reacoes quimicas e processos industriais

steps.conclusion: The response makes appropriate use of Physics concepts (thermodynamics, energy conservation, waste heat recovery) and creates realistic engineering scenarios with genuine trade-offs.

The instructions explicitly state to use '2-4 different dimensions total' and that dimensions must be 'consistent across all steps'. The response uses 6 unique dimensions ('Eficiencia Energética', 'Complejidad Operativa', 'Costo Operativo', 'Flexibilidad Operativa', 'Inversión Inicial', 'Sostenibilidad'). While the dimensions are semantically appropriate for specific steps, using 6 violates the game mechanics constraint designed for a consistent UI dashboard.

To fix the dimension count, 'Inversión Inicial' could be merged into 'Costo Operativo' (representing overall financial health), and 'Sostenibilidad' could be represented by 'Eficiencia Energética' (as they are strongly correlated in this context) or substituted for 'Flexibilidad' in the final step. This would maintain the requested limit of 4 dimensions.

explanationSteps.text: La energia no se crea ni se destruye, solo se transforma. En cada conversion, la energia total se conserva, pero la energia util disminuye. Parte siempre se convierte en calor no aprovechable.
explanationSteps.title: Conservacion de la Energia

explanationSteps.text: La eficiencia mide cuanta energia de entrada se convierte en trabajo util. Ningun proceso es 100% eficiente — siempre hay perdidas. La segunda ley de la termodinamica lo garantiza.
explanationSteps.title: Eficiencia Energetica

explanationSteps.text: Las cadenas de conversion acumulan perdidas. Si cada paso es 90% eficiente, tres pasos dan 0.9³ = 73% eficiencia total. Menos conversiones significa menos perdidas.
explanationSteps.title: Perdidas en Cadena

explanationSteps.text: El almacenamiento de energia tiene su propio costo energetico. Cargar y descargar baterias pierde energia. Bombear agua cuesta arriba para hidroelectrica tambien. El almacenamiento no es gratis.
explanationSteps.title: Costo del Almacenamiento

explanationSteps.text: La densidad energetica importa. Combustibles fosiles almacenan mucha energia por kilogramo. Las baterias almacenan menos. Esto afecta que es practico para cada aplicacion.
explanationSteps.title: Densidad Energetica

userInput.lessonDescription: Aplicando principios de conservacion de energia para disenar y optimizar sistemas energeticos
userInput.lessonTitle: Conservacion de Energia en Sistemas Reales
